prompt_data.system_prompt: You are an expert at classifying comments as othering or not. Othering is a social and structural process by which individuals or groups are framed as fundamentally different from a dominant “we.” It involves assigning negative or reductive attributes, reinforcing boundaries, and positioning the “others” as inferior, alien, or outside belonging. Othering operates at interpersonal, cultural, and institutional levels, and functions to stabilize the identity and power of the dominant group while producing marginality, exclusion, and inequality for those who are othered. Answer in JSON format only with 'Othering' or 'None' for 'label' and a short sentence explaining your decision process in 'reasoning' and identify the target group in 'target'. Context keywords should help you understand the meaning of the text, but do not assume any additional information.
prompt_data.question: Is this statement othering or not? Only classify it as 'Othering' if you are above 90% certain.

demos.text: Those immigrants don't want to fit in; they'll never be like us.

answer.label: Othering
answer.reasoning: Creates a boundary, casts the group as unwilling outsiders, reinforces exclusion

demos.text: Unlike us, women are too emotional to make rational decisions.

answer.label: Othering
answer.reasoning: Essentializes and negatively stereotypes women as inherently deficient.

demos.text: People from that neighborhood are lazy and don't care about hard work.

answer.label: Othering
answer.reasoning: Attributes a negative trait to an entire group, erasing individuality

demos.text: She's not one of us, but at least she tries.

answer.label: Othering
answer.reasoning: Positions someone as an outsider while granting conditional tolerance.

demos.text: They just don't value freedom the way we do.

answer.label: Othering
answer.reasoning: Establishes an in-group (“we” as true holders of freedom) and frames “them” as lacking.

3.text: “Hi Kpop girl can I send you a pic of g-dragon” “Woohoo I can’t wait! Please send it right away!” “Here you go” *sends a pic of g-dragon with no make up* “Ugh! No you spoilt my day! Hehe!”

annotation.label: None
annotation.reasoning: The conversation is about sharing a picture of G-Dragon and does not involve framing any group as different or inferior.

4.text: Bruh, I don't even like g-dragon but his comment is accurate af in describing how you'd come off as some socially awkward neckbeard if you talked like that to a girl.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates a negative stereotype of someone based on their interests and perceived social awkwardness.
annotation.target: A K-pop fan, specifically a G-Dragon fan

2.text: “Hi Kpop girl can I send you a pic of g-dragon?” “Uhhh ok” (what the hell? this guy is so weird) “Here you go” *sends pic of g-dragon with no makeup* “Uhh thanks I guess” (Jesus I hope he never talks to me again)

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Positions the individual as fundamentally different and inferior due to their interests or behavior.

1.text: How to spoil a kpop fangirl's day. Tell her you want to send her a pic of g dragon. She'll be expecting something like this, but no. Send his candid pics without makeup. Amazing what makeup can do for guys too, not just girls.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates an in-group (K-pop fans who are "in" on the joke) and frames K-pop fangirls as gullible outsiders to be tricked.

5.text: "Bruh", you're stupid if you think I talked to any of my friends in the manner he posted. I wrote a condensed version of what I did, not verbatim. End result was just people being surprised by how k pop idols look without make up, nothing awkward. I think people on this subreddit project too much when it comes to social awkwardness based on their own inadequacies.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Implies that people who project social awkwardness are inadequate and insecure, framing them as "other" in relation to oneself.

6.text: > if you think I talked to any of my friends in the manner he posted. Good thing I don't actually think that, but the fact that you're even fantasising and joking about it says a lot. Nah, you come off as a loser who doesn't know how to speak to women without scaring them off. That's a sad fact man. Now bye loser

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates a boundary by framing someone as fundamentally different and inferior due to their perceived social awkwardness.

7.text: Eee. Disgusting sia, your mouth got hole?

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Uses derogatory language to dehumanize and degrade an individual or group.

8.text: I disagree with your first para, but I see your point for the rest of what you wrote. People need to realise identity is fluid and constructed. Just as a person can claim to be both Singaporean and Christian, they can also be Singaporean and Malayan. I honestly don't know see what's the big deal, and why FB comments are rife with siege mentality. It's like Singaporeans can't wait to start a losing war against Malaysia. Rabid nationalism is a disease that needs to be addressed.

annotation.label: None
annotation.reasoning: The statement critiques and challenges nationalism and siege mentality, promoting understanding of fluid identities and addressing harmful nationalism.

9.text: Hmm, I remember being in your situation, cept, I'm a guy. I think you can just tell them, of course, they'd still be worried. Mainly for daughters safety, and unwanted pregnancy.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates an in-group of individuals who share concerns about daughters' safety and positions those outside this group as less understanding or capable.

10.text: I have a couple-pair friends from primary school. Girl liked guy since around p6...? Girl's mother was strict too; no bf until 16 (but I think they got together secretly) Their wedding is coming later this month and I'm invited.

annotation.label: None

Lol When I turned 21 with a bf she asked when I’m going to give her grandkids. Moved in but didn’t marry at 24 and she got a shock when she found out we were sleeping on the same bed. What do you want, woman?!

annotation.label: None
annotation.reasoning: The statement does not frame any group as fundamentally different or inferior.

annotation.reasoning: Creates an in-group (the speaker and their gay friend) and positions the mother as an outsider who is uninformed or misinformed about the friend's sexual orientation.

annotation.label: None
annotation.reasoning: The statement does not frame any group as fundamentally different or inferior to another.

17.text: Thank you for introducing the once-ignorant me to such a magnificent subreddit

annotation.label: None

18.text: I find it stupid that youths nowadays are using the r-word. all the time. The word retard. Its offensive.

19.text: Well i kind of see them as outliers, in this day and age, the younger generations are so engaged in social media that it is hard to stay ignorant.

annotation.label: None
annotation.reasoning: Does not frame a group as fundamentally different or inferior.

20.text: There's still something called confirmation bias, and it affects some people more severely than others. There are still a lot of people who would remain ignorant with or without the internet.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates a division between those with access to information and those without, implying some people are inherently more susceptible to ignorance.
annotation.target: Those without internet access or less informed individuals

21.text: The % of Muslims is similar in both countries. The only *significant* difference is that Singapore has a much higher % of Christians and Catholics. So just to clarify - people from those two groups are bigots that preventing social progress. Let's call a spade a spade. >might not be worth removing a law that isn't enforced anyway. So this law is simultaneously meaningless while also being of such importance to cause harm? You can't really have it both ways.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates a binary opposition between two groups (Christians/Catholics and Muslims), framing Christians/Catholics as bigots preventing social progress while positioning Muslims as victims of this alleged bigotry.

22.text: > The % of Muslims is similar in both countries. The only significant difference is that Singapore has a much higher % of Christians and Catholics. So just to clarify - people from those two groups are bigots that preventing social progress. Let's call a spade a spade. Using your reasoning, the higher % of Christians and Catholics are also responsible for reducing the prevalence of sex crimes. If you use that line of thinking it cuts both ways.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates a binary opposition between two groups, framing one as progressive and the other as bigoted, while also making sweeping generalizations about religious groups.

23.text: >Using your reasoning, the higher % of Christians and Catholics are also responsible for reducing the prevalence of sex crimes. If you use that line of thinking it cuts both ways. Do Christians and Catholics speak out against sex crimes more than any other group in Singapore? Meanwhile, we know for a fact that those two religions are vehemently opposed to homosexuality. Please just look at things like the AWARE saga, NLB book fiasco or the Wear White campaign. So yeah, your argument makes no sense, because there's correlation for one issue while none for the other.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates a division between Christians/Catholics and others by implying they are uniquely responsible for reducing sex crimes and uniquely opposed to homosexuality.

24.text: Your thinking is too simplistic. Just because people don't vehemently speak out against homosexuality does not mean that they support LGBT. The method by which you "determined" correlation is laughably dumb. Saudi Arabia has no Catholics and Christians, why don't they have gay marriage as well? But its okay. You can continue labouring under the delusion that all that stands in the way of gay marriage are Christians and Catholics.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates an 'us versus them' dynamic by implying that Christians and Catholics are the primary obstacles to gay marriage, while ignoring or downplaying the role of other groups.

25.text: You are backtracking. Someone posted a bunch of reasons why Singapore as a whole may be opposed to LGBT outside of religion and your response was this: > "The only significant difference is that Singapore (as compared to India) has a much higher % of Christians and Catholics. So just to clarify - people from those two groups are bigots that preventing social progress. Let's call a spade a spade." Go ahead and try to shift the goal posts into "whether Christians and Catholics are opposed to LGBT". I'm done here.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Framing Christians and Catholics as bigots preventing social progress, implying they are inherently opposed to LGBT.

26.text: Ceddya's point is that there is a much higher % of Christians in Singapore, while the % of Muslims in Singapore and India are similar. Saudi Arabia on the other hand is practically the center of Islam, so it's not an apples-to-apples comparison.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates a distinction between Christians in Singapore and Muslims in other countries, framing them as fundamentally different due to their religious composition.

27.text: I fully understand ceddya's point. I just think he's misguided in believing that with regards to LGBT issues Singapore is "India except with a higher % of Christians". Even worse, the person he responded to already highlighted the myriad of different factors that make Singapore and India markedly different (to add, factors that may justify the government's stance). I won't be continuing this discussion any further, but thanks for taking a civil tone.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates an in-group of Christians and positions another group as different with a negative connotation.

28.text: If you can’t tell that’s literally swimming in disgusting black sauce, then we are truly lost. The chicken died for nothing!

annotation.label: None
annotation.reasoning: The statement does not frame any group as fundamentally different or inferior.

29.text: Rote learning is definitely a product of outdated teaching methods. But sometimes they have no choice but to focus on memorization because the fundamentals of kids are very weak. If they don't use the language frequently outside the classroom, they have to be taught like they are strangers to the language. And I think teaching with "a bunch of China stories" is the very basis of education and connection with racial heritage. No one complains about using books from the Western canon to teach English.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates an in-group of those familiar with Western canon and frames students of Mandarin as outsiders who need to be taught like strangers.

30.text: Stepping up when you’re an oppressed part of society sounds way easier than it actually is. It also doesn’t help that our society is mostly conservative.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates an us vs. them dynamic by implying that those who are part of the oppressed group have it easier than they actually do.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates an 'us versus them' dynamic by implying that some individuals are overly sensitive about oppression and misperceive their situation.

32.text: They are oppressed in that they are denied the basic right of public housing. In SG, you can't get a flat unless your marriage is legally recognised. Besides, it sucks for your relationship to technically be illegal.

annotation.reasoning: Denies basic rights to individuals based on their relationship status and sexual orientation, framing them as oppressed "others".

33.text: Well. Congrats on being an angry incel. At least you get access to public housing once you turn 35. I do feel that it sucks that the government doesn't provide more support to singles (especially single parents) when it comes to housing, but we were discussing about what discrimination gay couples face, not the issue of singles

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Positions a group as fundamentally different and inferior, with the term 'angry incel' being derogatory.

34.text: > unless your marriage is legally recognised You're the one who's intent on missing the fundamental point - you've done it elsewhere in this thread too. You're not stupid enough to be unable to understand this, so I have to believe you're being purposefully obtuse. You're welcome to stop if you want to try to achieve something.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Implies the individual is intentionally avoiding or missing a key issue and frames them as obstinate or insincere.

35.text: Arabilized? The arabisation of Muslims doesn't affect Singapore as much as other countries. Here arabisation usually is limited to traditions, culture and clothings ie wearing burqa when there's no sand here That being said political views do permeate some of them. But the arabisation of Malays in Singapore is generally less noticeable than Malays who are apathetic towards religion. They also usually are the middle aged group/older generation rather than the younger generation

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates an in-group of Singaporeans and implies that arabisation is more prevalent and problematic in other countries, while also framing certain Muslims as "other" due to their perceived cultural and religious practices.

36.text: I like to see this as a two-perspective issue: perception vs treatment. Women are *perceived* to be weaker, therefore they are *treated* better by the law. Men are *perceived* to be stronger, therefore the law *treats* them worse. So things like NS are men-only because women are perceived as too weak to handle it. Depending on how you look at it, you can see this as discrimination against either gender.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates a dichotomy between men and women based on perceived strength, reinforcing gender stereotypes.

37.text: >So things like NS are men-only because women are perceived as too weak to handle it. Hardly true. Women are allowed to serve in the army if they wish to.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates a gender-based distinction that frames women as inherently weaker and less capable.

38.text: Yes I'm still not getting your point. Can you provide high profile cases of where NS has caused an entity to wrongly assume that a woman is weaker, leading to that entity discriminating against that woman and denying her an opportunity that she was capable of handling?

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Implies that women are generally weaker and more prone to discrimination than men, reinforcing harmful stereotypes.

39.text: I'm still not seeing any actual problem. What's the actual harm to women that's caused by this mindset? Are they being denied any opportunities? What actual problem does this cause to women? All I can see are benefits to this and no disadvantages.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Framing women as inherently inferior by implying they are not being harmed or denied opportunities despite a mindset that treats them differently.

40.text: Why do you presume that just because someone sees women as weaker, it means that they are looking down and mocking them? Your analogy is terrible because it has no similarities to NS. Again, women have the choice to join the army. Men don't.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates an in-group of men and frames women as weaker and less capable, implying they are inherently inferior.

41.text: I don't. I'm just trying to explain the thought process. If the definition of discrimination is that one treats someone else differently not due to skills or something related, then treating women differently because they are weaker is by definition the discrimination. Nobody (iirc, this thing was yesterday) in this thread claimed that they were oppressed. It's just another way of thinking about it. Whether it fits the day-to-day "feel" for what definition means is another issue.

annotation.label: None
annotation.reasoning: The statement does not frame a group as fundamentally different or inferior but rather discusses discrimination against women in an abstract and neutral manner.

42.text: this is like plot twist for a lot of romance manga lol. awkward shy nerdy guy has a date with a vibrant cheery talkative girl, then turned to be expert in relationship stuff. edit: congrats though hope it goes well! :)

annotation.label: None

43.text: you say it like the "majority" conforms at all by allowing gay people to bang it literally does not affect us, as the majority, in any way by being removed, unless you're gay enough to care what gay people do in their bedrooms

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates a division between "us" (the majority) and "them" (gay people), implying that gay individuals are outside of the normative group and that their actions do not affect or concern the dominant group.

44.text: refer to my response to steepcliff below. There is no reason to remove the law. If anything, it would do as good to keep it. The police do not witchhunt for gay people engaging in sexual intercourse, why do they need to remove the law to do so? As long as it is consensual and does not hurt or abuse the other party involved, I do not see why the police would catch wind of it and come knocking.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Positions gay people as a group that needs protection from police persecution, framing them as vulnerable and in need of defense against potential abuse.

45.text: Historically, slavery was not abolished because the minority slaves asked and fought for it — any such rebellion would have been put down. Ironically, it was actually Christian activists (priests and evangelicals), moved by their moral convictions that slavery was wrong, that pushed for political change through democratic means. Source: https://www.britannica.com/topic/abolitionism-European-and-American-social-movement

annotation.label: None
annotation.reasoning: The statement is a historical account of abolitionism and does not frame any group as "other" or assign negative attributes.

46.text: It is true that police don’t go around enforcing it. But with this law in place it makes it feel as if being queer is wrong when it’s perfectly alright to love whoever you wanna love. It’s just one step towards being accepted and having equality. And if the law isn’t being enforced alrdy, why keep it? Removing the law won’t force straight ppl to be gay.

annotation.label: None
annotation.reasoning: The statement challenges existing power structures and laws that perpetuate inequality for a minority group (the LGBT community), advocating for equality and acceptance.

47.text: Would you care explaining how giving gay people equal rights will lead to a "crumble of society"?

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Implies that gay people are a threat to societal stability and order.

48.text: So I assume the same goes for infertile people? Them having sex must be illegal? Since you rank the concept of family so highly, should all married couples be forced to reproduce as well?

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Positions individuals or groups perceived as different from the dominant group in a negative light, framing them as threats to societal norms and values.

49.text: And how did gays cause Islamic overpopulation and slow internet speeds? If you're trolling, you're not a very good one. If you're not, you're not very smart. Either way, it doesn't reflect well on you.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: The statement frames a group (gays) as responsible for societal issues and insults them, creating an us versus them dynamic.

50.text: OMG you are literally a troll. Nobody is even accidentally this stupid.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Denigrates and dehumanizes an individual by calling them a derogatory term ('troll') and questioning their intelligence.

51.text: Your ideal society must be pretty weak and unstable if you believe that it can be toppled by guys getting it on with one another.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Implies a societal structure is inherently fragile due to the actions of a specific group (homosexual men), framing them as a threat to stability.

52.text: Wrong Well it is true that two cis men cannot give birth on their own, since they lack a womb among them. But there are of course ways around that. And two women usually will have a womb between them so most two-woman couples can give birth to a child

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates an exclusionary boundary based on biological differences and reproductive capabilities.

53.text: Even in places where LGBT people are well-accepted, people feel safe coming out, and are able to know that they themselves aren't straight/cis at a younger age, the proportion of LGBT people are still less than 10%. So I'd say that the majority of relationships will still be between men and women, just as it is now.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Implicitly suggests LGBT individuals are less common or less desirable than straight/cis people.

54.text: Is the phone youre using to reply now natural? Lethal diseases like measles are natural; vaccines that protect people from lethal diseases are unnatural, should we not get vaccinated and die from measles because it's natural? I don't get people who generalize natural always equals good. FYI, the animal kingdom do witness homosexual activities so homosexuality is ironically natural.

annotation.label: None
annotation.reasoning: The statement challenges the idea that 'natural' automatically means 'good', providing counterexamples and questioning overly simplistic views on nature.
annotation.target: People who believe natural things are always good

55.text: Answer my question about infertile people. And yes, people certainly want to choose to be executed, what a great choice. Just like how you choose to be straight, 10 year old kids also choose to be gay.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Implies that certain groups (infertile people, homosexuals) are unnatural or have made a choice to be that way.

56.text: Answer my question about infertile people. Tell me, when did you choose to be straight? And being gay is so much more about sucking dicks, it is about developing love for the same gender. Just because you are incapable of love doesn't mean others are.

annotation.reasoning: Creates a hierarchy of value based on sexual orientation and fertility status, implying that certain groups (infertile individuals, those who are not straight) are less capable of love or less valuable.

57.text: This is so ridiculous that it should be on a comedy show. How do you explain the wars in the Middle East and other Muslim countries, then? Homosexuality is illegal there. ​

58.text: Thing is, many of the country where homosexuality is illegal, suffer from overpopulation. By the have kids, argument then sex using contraception or sex with an infertile person should also be outlawed. Ireland legalized same-sex marriage a few years ago and it still has the highest birth rates in the EU. A non harming individual is important. Oppressing gay people for reproduction is wrong, you should promote tax breaks and compensations for people to have more kids .

annotation.reasoning: The statement does not frame any group as fundamentally different or inferior. Instead, it critiques laws that oppress gay people and suggests promoting tax breaks and compensations for having children.

59.text: For a start... ​ No teaching of children about homosexuality No housing benefits which are specifically for straight couples Dont start suing businesses who refuse to participate in your gay wedding

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates a boundary between an 'us' and a marginalized group ('them'), with negative framing of the latter.

60.text: How vast are we talking about here? I honestly think a good number of people can't be bothered to form a concrete view of the issue because it doesn't concern them. "Just follow what people say last time lor. They say gay not good means should be correct." Force these peope to sit down and have them put a little thought and reflection into these issues, and add a little empathy into the mix and we should see that this "vast majority" isn't as vast as we assume it to be.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Positions individuals who hold homophobic views as an out-group and implies they lack empathy or understanding.

61.text: Teaching children that it is ok to identify as gay/lesbian and the society wouldn't treat them unfairly, and their family would accept them for who they are, along with safe sex techniques isn't equality?

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates an in-group of "straight couples" and frames LGBTQ+ individuals as outside this group, implying they are not equal or accepted.

62.text: Maybe if children were taught actual facts about homosexuality, like it is not a lifestyle but it is how you are born and not the blatant lies circling around from religious groups etc, just maybe the rampant homophobia here would die down. You can't be taught to be gay, you can't be turned, you are born like that. And if a child or teenager figures out that they are gay, they should know and have been taught that that is okay, just as it is okay to be straight during sexual education. And THAT is equality.

annotation.label: None

63.text: Feeling guilty about treatment of your kids (and about other things in life too, really) is something that is deeply rooted in our upbringing and childhood. It's unlikely to be something one can rationalize away easily. However it's also very common. Typically, you need to first examine and identify the source of that guilt you feel as well as related self beliefs, then take steps to convince yourself and rewire your emotional cues. Therapy and similar services can help as can some books (pm if interested)

annotation.label: None
annotation.reasoning: Does not frame any group as fundamentally different or inferior.

71.text: I believe that's a bot, doubt the owner will reply to you. I agree with your comment. However, there are always some black sheep that keng/fake their way out of nice things for everything in life making the rest look bad when they have genuine issues/concerns.

72.text: I agree with your points based on an a genderless society where effort equals payoff. So feminists better don't keep harping for equality, you might just get what you wish for.
